questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the criteria used for the diagnosis of Bacterial vaginosis?

HPV 2 is typically associated with common skin warts and not anogenital lesions. It is crucial for healthcare professionals to distinguish between high-risk and low-risk HPV types to provide appropriate patient counselling and management.

questions.text: A college student came with painful grouped vesicles over genitalia. What will be next best investigation you want to perform and what could be the possible finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tzanck smear to detect Tzanck cells

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Gram stain to detect Gram-positive organisms
  • • Option A. Gram stain to detect Gram-positive organisms
  • • The Gram stain is used to classify bacteria as either Gram-positive or Gram-negative. This test is not appropriate for the clinical scenario described, as the presentation is not suggestive of a bacterial infection.
  • • The Gram stain is used to classify bacteria as either Gram-positive or Gram-negative.
  • • Gram-positive or Gram-negative.
  • • This test is not appropriate for the clinical scenario described, as the presentation is not suggestive of a bacterial infection.
  • • Option B. Skin biopsy to detect HP bodies
  • • Option B. Skin biopsy to detect HP bodies
  • • HP (Henderson-Patterson) bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions seen in molluscum contagiosum, which is not consistent with the presentation of painful genital vesicles. A skin biopsy is more invasive and not the first-line investigation in this scenario.
  • • HP (Henderson-Patterson) bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions seen in molluscum contagiosum, which is not consistent with the presentation of painful genital vesicles.

  • • Option C. SSS to detect Acid-fast bacilli
  • • Option C. SSS to detect Acid-fast bacilli
  • • An SSS (Slit Skin Smear) test for acid-fast bacilli is used in the diagnosis of leprosy , neither of which typically present as painful grouped vesicles in the genital area.

questions.text: A female married for 6 years and trying to conceive complaints of profuse non-foul smelling, non-itchy white discharge for 2 days. Her last menstrual period is 13-14 days back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Physiological

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Bacterial vaginosis
  • • Option A. Bacterial vaginosis
  • • Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is characterized by a foul-smelling discharge that is typically gray in color. It's also associated with a fishy odor , particularly after intercourse, which is not described in the presented case.
  • • Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is characterized by a foul-smelling discharge that is typically gray in color.

  • • Option B. Candidiasis
  • • Option B. Candidiasis
  • • Candidiasis, or a yeast infection, usually presents with a thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge that is accompanied by severe itching . The lack of itching and the texture of the discharge make this diagnosis less likely.
  • • Candidiasis, or a yeast infection, usually presents with a thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge that is accompanied by severe itching .
  • • thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge
  • • severe itching
  • • The lack of itching and the texture of the discharge make this diagnosis less likely.
  • • Option D. Trichomoniasis
  • • Option D. Trichomoniasis
  • • Trichomoniasis typically presents with a frothy, yellow-green discharge with a foul odor and may cause itching and irritation. The absence of these characteristics in the patient's description makes trichomoniasis an unlikely diagnosis.
  • • Trichomoniasis typically presents with a frothy, yellow-green discharge with a foul odor and may cause itching and irritation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with vaginal discharge and itching. Her male partner has no symptoms. Which of the following conditions necessitates treatment of the male partner?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  D) Trichomoniasis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A (Bacterial vaginosis):
  • • Option A (Bacterial vaginosis):
  • • This is an overgrowth of normal vaginal flora and is not considered a sexually transmitted infection. Routine treatment of the male partner is not recommended.
  • • This is an overgrowth of normal vaginal flora and is not considered a sexually transmitted infection.

  • • Option B (Herpes genitalis):
  • • Option B (Herpes genitalis):
  • • This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the herpes simplex virus. While sexual partners should be informed and preventive measures should be taken to avoid transmission, especially during outbreaks, treatment of the male partner is not required unless he shows symptoms.
  • • This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the herpes simplex virus. While sexual partners should be informed and preventive measures should be taken to avoid transmission, especially during outbreaks, treatment of the male partner is not required unless he shows symptoms.

  • • treatment of the male partner is not required
  • • Option C (Candidiasis):
  • • Option C (Candidiasis):
  • • This is a yeast infection caused by Candida species. It is not classified as a sexually transmitted infection, and treatment of the male partner is not typically necessary unless he shows symptoms of infection (e.g., balanitis).

questions.text: All of the following can be seen associated with Early congenital syphilis EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Seventh nerve palsy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Syphilitic rhinitis , commonly referred to as "snuffles," is frequently the first and most prevalent symptom of early congenital syphilis. A profuse, serous nasal discharge with a significant amount of Treponema pallidum is how it presents. Snuffles, Syphilitic pemphigus & Hepatosplenomegaly form the triad of Early Congenital syphilis. Due to the destruction of the nose's bone and cartilage in later stages, a saddle nose may develop. Congenital syphilis can spread intrapartum through lesions in the mother's genitalia or trans placentally from an infected mother. The primary and secondary stages of the disease are when the risk is greatest. It can result in fetal death or congenital syphilis in a live birth if untreated. The onset of congenital syphilis can be early or late . Early disease manifests within two years , while late disease does so after three years .

questions.text: After 14 hours of receiving Injection Penicillin for her early latent syphilis, a 35-year-old woman suddenly develops a high-grade fever, myalgia, and bone pain. Which of the following statements is FALSE with respect to her condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Penicillin cannot be used in future

options.label: C
options.text: Fever usually comes down within 8 hours

options.label: D
options.text: D Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction occurs within 24 hours of penicillin therapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Penicillin cannot be used in future
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Penicillin cannot be used in future

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A febrile reaction occurring within 24 hours of penicillin therapy for syphilis is suggestive of Jarisch-Herxheimer's reaction . Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is self-limiting and is due to lipoprotein release from the dying treponemes , which trigger cytokine release. The patient presents with flu-like symptoms and exacerbation of skin lesions . Fever rarely lasts more than 8 hours . Symptoms may be controlled by antipyretics . It is not a contraindication for penicillin use in the future. Penicillin allergy is a contraindication for further use. JH reactions must be differentiated from penicillin allergy . Constitutional Symptoms such as Fever, Joint Pain, Hypotension along with Worsening of Skin Lesions. Treatment : Symptomatic

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to Derma OPD with a painless and foul-smelling ulcer. On examination, there is no lymphadenopathy. The image below shows the microscopic analysis of a sample taken from a genital ulcer. Which of the following statements about this illness is FALSE?

options.label: B
options.text: It has an incubation period of 8 to 80 days

options.label: C
options.text: It has the potential for malignant transformation

questions.correct_answer: A. Primary ulcer heals without scarring
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given image shows Donovan bodies, which points to a diagnosis of Granuloma inguinale . The clinical picture of a painless, beefy red, foul-smelling ulcer with no lymphadenopathy is classical for Granuloma inguinale . Granuloma inguinale is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis / Klebsiella granulomatis . (Option D) The incubation period varies from 8-80 days , the average being 50 days. (Option B) The primary ulcer, if left untreated, heals spontaneously with scarring , or persists and spreads . (Option A) Untreated genital ulcers are followed by genital disfigurement and have the potential for malignant change. (Option C) Donovan bodies refer to the Gram-negative rod-shaped or oval organisms that show bipolar staining or safety-pin appearance , present intracellularly in the cytoplasm of large mononuclear cells.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman has come down with painful lesions as shown below. She tells you that vesicles were present 5 days back over the same site and says that she is allergic to penicillin. On examination, she has bilateral tender lymphadenopathy. Which kit will you use to treat her?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical picture of multiple, grouped painful ulcers with tender lymphadenopathy in this patient points to a diagnosis of herpes genitalis infection by HSV-2. It is treated with a red kit . In herpetic genital ulcer disease, treatment of asymptomatic partners is not required. The red kit or kit 5 is meant for genital ulcer disease - herpetic. It contains acyclovir 400 mg tablets to be taken TDS for 7 days . Chancroid, which manifests as numerous, tender soft, painful ulcers, & bilateral lymphadenopathy is a close differential diagnosis. Chancroid, on the other hand, lacks vesicles and has deeper ulcers with ragged, undermined edges. Only when the patient presents with the primary chancre of syphilis is the patient's history of penicillin drug allerg y relevant. They would need to be treated with a blue kit in this situation rather than a white kit.

questions.text: A young woman presents with painful deep ulcers on her genitals 4 days after unprotected sexual intercourse as shown below. She also has painful unilateral lymphadenopathy with suppurating buboes. What is the FALSE statement regarding this disease?

questions.text: A 40-year-old sexually active male presents to an STD clinic with painful genital sores as shown in the image below. He reports that the lesion appeared about two weeks ago and has been progressively worsening. On examination, you observe multiple painful bleeding ulcers with unilateral unilocular painful suppurative inguinal bubo. There are no other visible lesions, and the patient denies any systemic symptoms. He had multiple sexual partners in recent months. What is the most likely diagnosis?

  • • Differentiating features between Herpes genitalis & Chancroid:

  • • OPTION B:
  • • Syphilis (Primary Stage)
  • • The primary lesion of syphilis is the chancre, which is a solitary, painless ulcer with a clean base and i ndurated borders. The patient's presentation of multiple painful ulcers with a painful inguinal bubo does not fit the primary syphilis picture.

While there are similarities in the ulcer presentation between chancroid and donovanosis, the painful and suppurative inguinal bubo described in the case is more characteristic of chancroid.

questions.text: Which of the following are true about chancroid? School of fish appearance Bleeds on touch Painful ulcer Grooves sign
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2 & 3 only are correct

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Chancroid: It is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi . It is characterized by painful ulcers on the genitalia and swelling of the inguinal lymph nodes . Here are the characteristics based on the given options:

  • • Haemophilus ducreyi
  • • painful ulcers
  • • genitalia
  • • swelling
  • • inguinal lymph nodes
  • • School of fish appearance: This term is typically used to describe the Gram stain appearance of Haemophilus ducreyi , where the bacteria appear in a parallel arrangement resembling a "school of fish." Bleeds on touch : Chancroid ulcers can be very tender and may bleed when touched or during cleaning. Painful ulcer : A defining feature of chancroid is that the ulcer is painful, which is in contrast to the painless ulcer typically seen in syphilis. Groove sign: The groove sign is classically associated with lymphogranuloma venereum , not chancroid. It refers to the presence of a groove between two swollen lymph nodes, usually in the inguinal area.

questions.text: Which among the following presents with painful genital ulcers? Hemophilus ducreyi Neisseria gonorrhea Chlamydia trachomatis Herpes simplex virus
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Only 1 & 4 are correct.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hemophilus ducreyi is the causative agent of chancroid , a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful genital ulcers. Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes gonorrhea , which typically presents with urethritis in men and may be asymptomatic or cause cervicitis in women. It does not typically cause painful genital ulcers. Chlamydia trachomatis causes chlamydia, which can result in cervicitis in women and urethritis in men , but like gonorrhea, it is not typically associated with painful genital ulcers. Herpes simplex virus causes genital herpes , which is characterized by painful genital ulcers or blisters .
  • • Hemophilus ducreyi is the causative agent of chancroid , a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful genital ulcers.
  • • Hemophilus ducreyi
  • • chancroid
  • • painful genital ulcers.
  • • Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes gonorrhea , which typically presents with urethritis in men and may be asymptomatic or cause cervicitis in women. It does not typically cause painful genital ulcers.
  • • Neisseria gonorrhoeae
  • • gonorrhea
  • • urethritis
  • • asymptomatic or cause cervicitis
  • • Chlamydia trachomatis causes chlamydia, which can result in cervicitis in women and urethritis in men , but like gonorrhea, it is not typically associated with painful genital ulcers.
  • • Chlamydia trachomatis
  • • cervicitis in women
  • • urethritis in men
  • • Herpes simplex virus causes genital herpes , which is characterized by painful genital ulcers or blisters .
  • • Herpes simplex virus
  • • genital herpes
  • • painful genital ulcers or blisters

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When evaluating a patient for sexually transmitted infections, it is crucial to differentiate between organisms that cause painful genital ulcers such as Hemophilus ducreyi (chancroid) and Herpes simplex virus (genital herpes), and those that do not typically cause such ulcers like Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. Accurate diagnosis is essential for effective treatment and prevention of transmission.
